description: Borrowed from French cabotage (“coasting trade”), from caboter (“to travel by the coast”). It originally (16th c.) referred to restrictions allowing only French ships to trade or transport between French ports. Other countries adopted this concept and extended it to land and air travel.

entries.meaning: The transport of goods or passengers between two points in the same country.
(law) The right to engage in such transport.
examples: Cabotage, used as a legal term, here refers to the right to transport goods or passengers between ports of a country.

entries.meaning: The exclusive right of a country to control such transport.
